title: Episode 69 – Corona Virus Special w/ Ryan Zinn, Dr. Bronner’s Regen. Projects. Mgr.
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[8.9s - 15.3s]: Welcome to the Y-Honors Community Podcast. Today we are visiting with Ryan Zinn,

[15.8s - 19.1s]: Regenerative Projects Manager at Dr. Bronners. Hey Ryan.

[20.6s - 21.3s]: Hey there, how's it going?

[21.8s - 23.0s]: Good, how you doing?

[24.0s - 29.8s]: You know, not so bad just sort of adjusting to this new reality here when the days and times

[29.8s - 31.0s]: of coronavirus for sure.

[31.8s - 36.8s]: Yeah, absolutely. Yeah, we're going to have a lot to talk about in terms of coronavirus.

[37.3s - 43.2s]: Obviously, you're in the soap business. We've got supply chain issues. All of this relates

[43.2s - 48.8s]: also to the sustainability and regeneration work that you're doing all around the planet.

[49.1s - 52.5s]: So I'm really looking forward to our discussion today.

[53.4s - 57.4s]: Yeah, I'm excited. We're in a very dynamic and changing world.

[57.8s - 63.9s]: And you know, it's funny to think sometimes how a soap company could be really caught up in the middle of it.

[64.0s - 66.0s]: So I'm excited about our conversation, Aaron.

[66.8s - 71.4s]: Great. Well, let me give our audience a bit of a background on you.

[73.3s - 81.8s]: Ryan Zinn supports Dr. Bronners International Organic and Fair Trade Supply Chains in Africa, Asia, and the Pacific.

[82.5s - 92.3s]: Ryan has worked the last 20 years with small scale farmer organizations to develop agro-ecological strategies that are just and resilient.

[93.4s - 101.1s]: Ryan also supports nonprofit partners like the Fair Trade Advocacy Organization, Fair World Project,

[101.6s - 106.2s]: and the small farmer crowdfunding platform called Grow Ahead.

[107.2s - 113.4s]: And we're going to be mentioning a number of different resources and some videos through our conversation.

[113.6s - 117.6s]: And we'll have links to all those in the show notes for folks to reference.

[118.0s - 122.9s]: So Ryan, yeah, here we are. And we're dealing with COVID-19.

[124.0s - 127.8s]: You're in California. You're at home. Your kids are also at home.

[128.3s - 135.1s]: Maybe just as a place to start just because we're all one way or another in this experience together.

[137.0s - 142.5s]: How's your day been today? And what's going on in your world right now with the coronavirus?

[143.7s - 151.2s]: Yeah, it's a little while. I usually start my day pretty early, mostly because most of our partners are either in Asia or Africa.

[151.7s - 155.7s]: And so that gives me an opportunity to either, if I need to touch base with them and I tell you why,

[155.8s - 162.4s]: if it wasn't for Zoom and Skype we'd be in a whole lot of trouble these days since all of our travel to all of our partner projects has been really slowed down.

[162.4s - 170.9s]: I am just hunkering down from the time being. I've got my two children here at home. I've got a teenager and a twin-ager.

[171.6s - 177.8s]: And then I've got my wife who is a pediatric nurse who's also wrapping up her master's in nurse practitioner at UCLA.

[178.6s - 185.7s]: So everybody's gone virtual, which has been a big change for them to think through their academic life now online.

[186.1s - 189.3s]: And we're just trying to figure it all out now.

[190.1s - 198.4s]: Yeah, absolutely. Well, we know for certain that what's happening right now is definitely having an impact on the SOAP companies.

[199.3s - 206.9s]: And I'm really curious to ask, I'm assuming that demand has just skyrocketed for the Dr. Bronner's products.

[207.9s - 215.5s]: What does that look like in the immediate term? But also, what does that mean over the coming weeks and months in terms of supply chain procurement?

[215.5s - 220.4s]: And how resilient are those supplies coming from all around the world?

[222.2s - 230.4s]: That's a great question, Aaron. So I think the good news is that we've been demoned by the state of California and the county of San Diego as a quote-unquote essential business.

[230.8s - 236.4s]: Certainly, SOAP enhanced annotations will be in high demand for the foreseeable future.

[236.7s - 241.0s]: And as such, all our sales have been really booming, which is great on the one hand.

[241.0s - 243.7s]: And then I form a part of a really small team.

[243.7s - 250.4s]: And our job really is to work with our partners on the ground that produced all of our raw materials and sort of build out our supply chains.

[250.6s - 255.9s]: So that includes everything from coconut oil and palm oil on all the way to our essential oils like mint oil.

[256.2s - 260.5s]: And right now, our biggest challenge is working with farmers on the ground.

[260.9s - 269.6s]: Since many of the countries or regions have actually been facing some sort of variation of either full quarantine or shutdown or limited operation.

[269.6s - 273.9s]: And that's kind of, I think, something that is often overlooked.

[274.3s - 277.1s]: In fact, it's like you have farmers on the front end of this.

[277.3s - 278.9s]: We work with 10,000 small farmers.

[279.5s - 282.9s]: Many of them are working in relatively impoverished communities.

[283.5s - 288.9s]: And our goal is to not only provide them with a sustained fair trading relationship with Dr. Bronners,

[289.3s - 291.0s]: but make sure that they're thriving as well.

[291.1s - 294.7s]: And so if they are more or less quarantined to their farmer or to their home,

[294.7s - 297.9s]: then make many other food servers here in the United States.

[298.3s - 299.1s]: They don't have an income.

[299.4s - 301.2s]: They can't put food on the table.

[301.7s - 306.9s]: And so not only is it important for our bottom line, but we're really committed to their livelihoods as well.

[307.3s - 313.8s]: So just to give you an example, hand sanitizer, which is now flying off the shelves everywhere.

[314.3s - 317.4s]: We work with small-scale farmers in Paraguay and Ecuador.

[318.4s - 324.4s]: And our farmers, partners in Ecuador, they are just stuck at home because they have a full-on 15-day quarantine.

[324.4s - 328.4s]: So they won't actually be able to get their product to port and ship to us.

[328.7s - 331.1s]: So we're trying to be as creative as possible.

[331.6s - 339.7s]: Certainly, we don't want to abandon our partners in a time of need and go with another sort of cheaper alternative or quicker alternative.

[340.2s - 344.2s]: But we also need to make sure that we can continue to make so-open hand sanitizer and the rest of our product.

[344.4s - 349.1s]: So I think on top of the day-to-day work that we do, which has its own challenges,

[349.1s - 355.7s]: certainly overlaying COVID-19 on top of it, provides another regal that we have to just kind of think through and be pretty creative.

[356.6s - 364.0s]: Absolutely. Well, I know that you and the team at Dr. Bronner's are extraordinarily creative and really on the forefront,

[364.2s - 368.5s]: the cutting edge of the regenerative and the sustainable movements worldwide.

[368.9s - 378.4s]: And I'm so excited to ask you about the ways in which you guys are supporting regenerative agricultural practices around the world.

[378.4s - 383.6s]: And what does that mean? I know a lot of our audiences are familiar with the term regenerative.

[383.7s - 387.1s]: Some of our audience works in the regenerative realm.

[387.4s - 393.7s]: But of course, we also have a lot of folks who are just getting acquainted with the term and what it means.

[394.1s - 402.0s]: And clearly, this is going to become a very, very important action item for us all around the planet.

[402.3s - 404.2s]: And you guys are leading the way.

[404.2s - 408.1s]: So regenerative agriculture, what is it and what are you guys doing?

[409.2s - 416.1s]: Well, I mean, I think for us, you know, our sort of journey towards this space in 2020 kind of starts about 15 years ago.

[416.7s - 423.8s]: When the Bronner family made this commitment to convert and transfer all of our raw materials or coconut oil, for example,

[423.9s - 430.2s]: over to organic sources, what we quickly realized is that without having a lot of, I don't know,

[430.2s - 435.0s]: inside into your supply chains, it's really hard to tell if the integrity is there for organic.

[435.5s - 438.9s]: Certainly, we didn't know about the working conditions, whether farmers were paid fairly.

[439.6s - 443.5s]: And so as a result, we were more or less forced to set up our own supply chains.

[444.1s - 449.0s]: So back about 15 years ago, we set up our first supply chain in Sri Lanka to produce coconut oil,

[449.4s - 451.7s]: which is our number one ingredient in most of our soaps.

[452.1s - 458.7s]: And as a result, we did that not only to have organic integrity, so that we can ensure that the consumer has

[459.2s - 462.8s]: a product free from pesticides and is grown sustainably.

[463.3s - 466.3s]: But certainly, we also wanted to produce under fair trade conditions as well.

[466.5s - 469.2s]: So that means that farmers are paid fair prices, they're paid promptly.

[469.8s - 474.4s]: We're not going to abandon them if they face a drought or COVID-19 or what have you.

[474.9s - 477.3s]: And so we wanted to make sure that that was really our foundation.

[477.9s - 481.1s]: And over time, what we realized is that we really wanted to take it further.

[481.4s - 487.6s]: And so we've kind of been approaching this idea of regenerative organic agriculture as a way to not only

[488.2s - 491.1s]: ensure that we have a stable supply chain for ourselves for sure.

[491.6s - 495.7s]: But really, I think the big thing is thinking it through the lens of climate change.

[496.1s - 501.2s]: So what we know is that climate change has already been having a big impact on farmers around the world,

[501.8s - 504.1s]: whether they call it climate change or something else.

[504.2s - 506.1s]: But really, if it were like the past 10 or 20 years,

[506.7s - 512.0s]: we'd be seeing increases of crop loss, more pest and disease problems for farmers.

[512.5s - 515.9s]: And this is leading to all sorts of things, migration to the cities,

[516.6s - 518.1s]: losing land, those types of things.

[518.3s - 524.4s]: And so our goal is to really improve our practices on the ground under this sort of banner of

[524.4s - 525.4s]: regenerative organic.

[525.6s - 529.7s]: And really what that means is a couple of different things just in terms of general principles.

[529.9s - 533.3s]: One, in nature, nature has no monoculture.

[533.5s - 538.7s]: So really, our focus is to diversify as much as we can with our small farmer partners.

[538.7s - 543.1s]: And that means to them to diversify into other crops and other systems that,

[543.1s - 546.5s]: quite frankly, we may never actually use in our own supply chains to make soap.

[547.0s - 552.6s]: So for example, in Ghana and West Africa, where we see a number of our farmers actually grow

[552.6s - 559.4s]: cocoa to make chocolate, there it's a very, very heavily pesticide dependent crop, where they

[559.4s - 563.9s]: just sprayed, fund aside, left and right just because of the climatic conditions and the practices.

[564.5s - 569.4s]: And so our goal is to get those farmers off the pesticide treadmill, improve their practices,

[569.4s - 573.6s]: which will not only improve their resiliency and improve their food security,

[574.3s - 576.4s]: but also provide some additional income.

[577.0s - 580.8s]: While we are able to provide fair prices for the products that we buy,

[581.5s - 584.0s]: the rest of the marketplace, quite frankly, is just not fair.

[584.4s - 588.5s]: And so we want to make sure that we can find fair prices for virtually everything that farmers

[588.5s - 593.7s]: produce, whether that is sold and distributed in local markets, or we find them premium buyers

[593.7s - 595.2s]: in the United States or in Europe.

[596.1s - 602.3s]: Well, that's tremendous. You guys are going well above and beyond your own direct needs and

[602.3s - 605.0s]: interests with these farmers. That's really remarkable.

[606.3s - 612.7s]: Yeah, for us, it's been a slow process. When you start to convert farmers from these long,

[613.0s - 618.7s]: sort of seeded experience of using chemicals to farm, it's a long sort of transitional

[618.7s - 623.6s]: process. And so what we want to do is accompany farmers during that process, but also provide them

[623.6s - 628.2s]: incentives so that they can sort of, you know, whether the changes that they are facing on the

[628.2s - 631.8s]: ground themselves, you know, quite frankly, depending on what you grow. Sometimes organic may

[631.8s - 635.7s]: have higher labor costs, for example, or require you to spend more time out in your field.

[636.1s - 642.5s]: So we want to make sure that as much as possible, really the true cost, what it takes to produce

[642.5s - 647.6s]: a regenerative and fair product is reflected in our relationship with farmers.

[648.6s - 652.8s]: You know, it's interesting. I've spoken with a number of farmers over the years about the

[653.6s - 661.3s]: often the increased labor requirements associated with organic practices. But on the other hand,

[661.3s - 668.2s]: there's an offset coming from no longer needing to buy these expensive chemical inputs. And I'm

[668.2s - 674.6s]: curious with these farmers you've worked with in general, how does their economic performance

[675.2s - 680.7s]: trend over time as they convert to organic and then build in a regenerative framework?

[682.0s - 687.1s]: I would say it really varies from place to place. You know, some places you have quite a bit more

[687.1s - 693.3s]: labor, depending on the cropping, you know, system. So for example, all of the mint that we use in our,

[693.5s - 699.5s]: or mint oil we use in our, you know, most famous peppermint, so comes from Uttar Pradesh and in India,

[699.6s - 706.4s]: where they grow mint to make essential oils, but the rotations as well, things from wheat,

[706.4s - 712.2s]: paddy rice and those types of things. And so really our goal is to figure out a way to support them

[712.2s - 717.6s]: during that transition period where in some cases their cost may go up because of labor, for example,

[717.9s - 723.3s]: or their yields may go down. But once our experiences is once you get over the hump that that

[723.3s - 727.4s]: transitional period where you actually certified organic, you can receive that organic premium,

[728.1s - 731.9s]: then you know, things begin to balance out quite a bit better in the favor of farmers.

[731.9s - 736.7s]: Really kind of our goal, you know, once we go through this transition period that's both required

[736.7s - 741.6s]: for the marketplace, but also just for soil to kind of like come back alive again and to be able

[741.6s - 747.0s]: to produce healthily, then you have many, many more options. And so after that sort of investment

[747.0s - 751.3s]: of time and if you're growing, you know, tree crops, there's quite a bit of investment in terms of

[751.3s - 756.2s]: ceilings, for example. We want to make sure that farmers have sort of a stable diversified sort of

[756.2s - 761.6s]: farm economy that can sort of, you know, whether the the, the changing either climatic conditions or even

[761.6s - 766.7s]: the market conditions. Yeah, yeah, that's really interesting. Well, speaking of the peppermint,

[766.7s - 772.8s]: Dr. Bronner's soap, I've got some of that in my bathroom. So I'm a daily user in a big fan.

[774.4s - 779.6s]: Well, I'm wondering, can you help connect the dots a little more and paint more of a picture for folks?

[780.0s - 785.9s]: What is the connection between regenerative agriculture, soil and climate crisis?

[786.8s - 791.1s]: Sure. Okay, so that's a really good question, Aaron. You know, one of the things that we often

[791.1s - 795.9s]: think about when we think about climate change that either it's, you know, sort of exhaust coming

[795.9s - 801.6s]: out of cars, tailpipes or, you know, factories spewing contaminants into the atmosphere, sort of on the,

[801.6s - 806.3s]: you know, emissions end of things. Or we also think of things like solar panels, for example,

[806.9s - 811.2s]: as a way to kind of mitigate against some of the bigger and broader kind of climate change

[811.2s - 817.1s]: challenges. What most folks may not realize is that agriculture or industrialized agriculture,

[817.1s - 823.4s]: in fact, is one of the larger, you know, sources of greenhouse gases. So everything from,

[823.4s - 830.1s]: you know, mechanized agriculture is a big combine of tractors to the production of food, for example,

[830.2s - 836.1s]: infertilizers, pesticides. But even just the simple fact of turning over soil and like plowing

[836.1s - 841.8s]: and very heavily actually releases carbon stored in that soil into the atmosphere. And so this sort

[841.8s - 846.2s]: of quote unquote, you know, industrial agricultural experience we've been doing now for the last six

[846.2s - 852.5s]: or 70 years has actually created quite a bit of greenhouse gas emissions, you know, that have been

[852.5s - 858.0s]: going up into the atmosphere. So we see a lot of potential for regenerative agriculture to not only

[858.0s - 863.1s]: stop those emissions, but actually sort of restore this carbon cycle, which basically means that

[863.1s - 869.0s]: soil can act as a carbon sink, suck all that CO2 out of the atmosphere, put it into the soil,

[869.3s - 873.7s]: which is not only beneficial for the climate, but it's also really, really important for plants

[873.7s - 878.9s]: and healthy soil. Although that turns into actual sort of nutrients to have a very healthy soil

[878.9s - 884.0s]: profile. And so that's been pretty much our goal in terms of how we've been approaching farming

[884.0s - 889.3s]: at all of our projects. Really, it's, this really combination is to implement practices that's a

[889.3s - 894.9s]: Quester carbon, we're appropriate, but also build up our soil health. And so that's one of the things

[894.9s - 899.8s]: that is probably, you know, a very simple concept to do, but it's one thing that really provides a

[899.8s - 903.9s]: lot of stability for farmers. They're able to actually absorb those climate shocks, where they're

[903.9s - 909.5s]: it's drought, not enough rain, too much rain, high temperatures, those types of things. But it also

[909.5s - 915.1s]: acts as a way for us to sort of turn back on some of the damage we've been doing through climate

[915.1s - 920.4s]: change. So really, our kind of focus here is to see agriculture done regeneratively and organically

[920.4s - 926.8s]: as a way for us to address multiple things at once. Turn back climate change, have farmers feed

[926.8s - 931.3s]: our local communities and to be able to produce a product like Dr. Brotter's soap that's done in a

[931.3s - 937.9s]: way that's fairly and as cleanly as possible. Yeah, absolutely. And one of the things that here

[937.9s - 945.1s]: at the Y on Earth community, obviously, we really emphasize for folks is the critical role that each

[945.1s - 952.7s]: of us as individuals plays as a consumer with our purchasing decisions where we're directing our

[952.7s - 958.2s]: consumer demand signals. And I'm wondering, can you speak to a bit about the dynamics that you see

[958.2s - 964.7s]: out in the marketplace? And of course, it's a it's a segue into the regenerative organics

[964.7s - 970.6s]: certification that I know we're all really, really excited about. But what do you see out there in

[970.6s - 976.0s]: the marketplace in terms of the importance of the consumer demand signals? Well, one thing I think

[976.0s - 982.5s]: which has been really exciting for me is that one, I think consumers, ethical consumers are seeing

[982.5s - 988.2s]: that they want to go quote unquote above and beyond organic and maybe even fair trade. And they're

[988.2s - 993.1s]: seeing climate change as one of the big existential threats that it is not only to their communities,

[993.4s - 997.7s]: but to the foods that they like. You know, I always tell folks if you really want to get freaked out,

[998.0s - 1003.0s]: you know, above and beyond COVID-19, just type in your favorite food into Google and climate change,

[1003.0s - 1009.1s]: whether it's chocolate, coffee, wine, bread, there's been a huge number of sort of like, you know,

[1009.1s - 1012.5s]: evidences and impacts that were seen throughout different supply chains. And so I think

[1012.5s - 1017.6s]: consumers are becoming increasingly savvy about that. And so as a result of all the fine work that's

[1017.6s - 1022.4s]: been done by, you know, farmers organizations and other nonprofits and NGOs, I think farmers are

[1022.4s - 1027.2s]: produced consumers are really looking to to make sure that that consumer dollar that they're

[1027.2s - 1032.4s]: spending really goes to those products that reflect their values. It's not just enough to be organic

[1032.4s - 1037.4s]: or just enough to be fair trade. They want to basically look at the suite of values altogether

[1037.4s - 1042.1s]: on one product. And so I think that of course is actually very, very encouraging. It means that we've

[1042.1s - 1046.5s]: got this sort of emerging consumer base that's really willing to put their money where their

[1046.5s - 1051.0s]: mouth is, but I think it's really positive. On the other hand, what you have now in the marketplace,

[1051.5s - 1055.8s]: other than, you know, claims like organic, for example, which is regulated at the federal level,

[1056.2s - 1059.8s]: you're seeing all sorts of claims in the marketplace that's regenerative of this or free-range that.

[1060.1s - 1065.1s]: And none of these claims are in fact regulated or have any basically, you know, sort of assurance behind

[1065.1s - 1069.9s]: them. And so one of the things that we did at Dr. Bronner's was look to connect with other

[1069.9s - 1076.0s]: like-minded organizations and companies to create a standard and process that really put a whole

[1076.0s - 1082.2s]: lot of sort of like, force and that validity behind the claims. And so we partnered with the

[1082.2s - 1087.7s]: Rhode Island Institute out of Pennsylvania, Patagonia, and a number of other NGOs and farmers'

[1087.8s - 1093.1s]: organizations to create a draft or pilot standard called the regenerative organic certification

[1093.1s - 1098.4s]: or rock standard. And so from there, our goal was really to be able to try to bring together all

[1098.4s - 1104.2s]: of our imported values. So organic certainly was there, fairness, performers and farm workers

[1104.2s - 1110.0s]: was certainly front and center, and then also looking at soil health and animal welfare.

[1110.5s - 1114.9s]: You know, one of the things that we look at is like when we look at a farm or a product,

[1115.3s - 1118.5s]: we want to make sure that all those values are there. Well, it's really tough for a consumer to

[1118.5s - 1122.9s]: try to figure that out all on their own. Heck, I'm, you know, in this business and sometimes it's

[1122.9s - 1126.8s]: also tough for me when I go to the supermarket to figure out if the claims that a product

[1126.8s - 1132.6s]: are making are in fact real or just re-washing. So our goal was to be able to create a standard

[1132.6s - 1137.2s]: that reflects our values and then can be verified, which means that a third party will go out and

[1137.2s - 1142.7s]: certify to it. And then the consumer can know that, hey, look, all my values are encapsulated in

[1142.7s - 1149.5s]: this product. Yeah, that's so powerful. Well, we're really excited about the regenerative organic

[1150.0s - 1154.8s]: certification and the why on earth community, I know is going to be doing a whole lot in the coming

[1154.8s - 1160.1s]: months to help build awareness, educate and mobilize around that out in the marketplace.

[1161.4s - 1168.0s]: And, you know, it makes me think also about a lot of the other ways in which we're all engaged in

[1168.0s - 1174.5s]: cultivating a more regenerative oriented culture. And I know you have some thoughts about

[1175.2s - 1182.0s]: what living regeneratively means in addition to whatever soap we might choose to buy.

[1182.7s - 1188.3s]: What are some of those? Well, I tell you what, I mean, it's actually, you know, maybe the one

[1188.3s - 1194.4s]: silver lining of the COVID-19 crisis is that, you know, it's really kind of forced our hand to do

[1194.4s - 1200.0s]: two things. I think one is to look like our at our own home. You know, I saw a couple of stats

[1200.0s - 1206.1s]: really in the last maybe 10 days where, you know, the sales of organic seeds have just gone through

[1206.1s - 1212.0s]: the roof. And so I see that as a really positive step. Even if it's a really small, you know,

[1212.1s - 1216.1s]: couple of containers of herbs you have on your porch or your balcony or, you know, on your windows

[1216.1s - 1222.4s]: seal or you can vert your entire front lawn to a home garden, I think those are really powerful

[1222.4s - 1229.9s]: connection because I think on multiple levels, one, if we can actually actively participate in the

[1229.9s - 1234.2s]: growing of our own food, even if it's relatively smaller, symbolic. I think there's just a very

[1235.3s - 1238.8s]: clear connection that you would see with the rest of the food that you buy. You have a greater

[1238.8s - 1244.4s]: appreciation that all of the work that farmers and farm workers go through and how hard it is and

[1244.4s - 1250.1s]: what an enchanted is to actually get fair and organic food to your front door, to your super

[1254.6s - 1260.1s]: is that there's more and more examples liberation happening right now, which I think is really,

[1260.1s - 1265.4s]: really critical. I don't think any of us can go it alone. Doesn't matter how much money we have or

[1265.4s - 1270.4s]: how much space we have to grow, whatever we have, I think being able to collaborate and depend upon

[1270.4s - 1273.9s]: your neighbors, I think is really, really critical. So I've seen some really great examples just

[1273.9s - 1278.9s]: in the last week of people working together either to help their neighbor go get, you know, they're

[1283.5s - 1288.4s]: street for those folks that didn't get any toilet paper because somebody was hoarding them. So

[1288.4s - 1294.3s]: it was a great way for us to be able to say how can we collaborate in a way and, you know,

[2671.1s - 2677.0s]: that we do at Dr. Bronners. So for example, the executive pay is capped at five to one. So

[2677.0s - 2683.0s]: David Bronner can't make more than five times what the lowest person pays. So really our goal is to

[2683.0s - 2688.4s]: make sure that we have living wages, universal health color for our staff. And we see that it's

[2688.4s - 2693.1s]: absolutely critical not just for our own team and our own company, but we want that for everybody.

[2693.6s - 2697.7s]: And really the only way to do that is to have a government program that allows for that and

[2697.7s - 2702.7s]: is equitable as possible. And I would just say one sort of concrete way that I like to explain this

[2702.7s - 2708.5s]: is one thing that you might realize going to the supermarket or your farmer's market, regenerative

[2708.5s - 2713.4s]: and organic products, they're expensive for sure. And that's in part because we've actually

[2714.0s - 2720.8s]: incorporated the true cost where we're paying the farmer fairly, where we are making sure that

[2720.8s - 2725.3s]: he or she is awarded for all of the investment that they're doing to make a regenerative organic

[2725.3s - 2731.3s]: product. And so for consumers to be able to actually pay a farm or the true cost, they need to be

[2731.3s - 2735.9s]: paid fairly as well. So that means raising the minimum wage, we want to have a living wage for

[2735.9s - 2740.3s]: everybody so that way we can actually support this regenerative economy that we would like to see

[2740.3s - 2747.1s]: in the future. Yeah, it's so important. And just to underscore the commitment that you all have

[2747.8s - 2755.1s]: already instituted at Dr. Bronner's to have a five to one executive paycap is extraordinary.

[2755.9s - 2761.9s]: We know in many of the corporations in here in the United States, we've got executives getting

[2761.9s - 2768.6s]: paid 100, 200, 300 times what many of their employees are being paid. And in this case,

[2769.2s - 2775.1s]: the highest level executive is getting paid only five times what the rest of the team are getting paid.

[2775.6s - 2781.1s]: Yeah, so that allows for us to pay living wages to everybody whether you're starting off even

[2781.1s - 2787.6s]: interns. We have we actually are able to provide a living wage for interns, which is pretty unique.

[2787.9s - 2792.4s]: I mean, I for one was, you know, when did a huge debt just trying to intern for, you know,

[2792.4s - 2797.3s]: other nonprofits and so for us to be able to do that, I think is a great example. And it just

[2797.3s - 2802.2s]: does the show you with this sort of commitment. You can actually do some pretty remarkable things.

[2802.5s - 2806.5s]: I had it to the broader family for doing these things. They do fantastic work.

[2807.6s - 2813.0s]: You know, it reminds me of a wonderful quote that I've seen attributed to Gandhi that says,

[2813.3s - 2822.3s]: the world has enough for everyone's need, but not for everyone's greed. And I think, you know,

[2822.3s - 2829.8s]: what you guys are doing at Dr. Bronners is such an exemplary example of what's possible,

[2830.0s - 2836.4s]: what needs to be done, what we should be supporting. And I want to thank you, Ryan, in the context of

[2836.4s - 2845.2s]: all of the disruption and, you know, this orientation that's happening right now with

[2845.2s - 2851.9s]: coronavirus, thank you so much for taking time to visit with us. And before we sign off, I just,

[2859.1s - 2861.7s]: And on behalf of the audience, I'll thank you again.

[2862.6s - 2867.6s]: Well, thank you, and I really appreciate the opportunity. I love all of the different

[2867.6s - 2871.9s]: activities that you all are doing just between education and giving people this concrete

[2871.9s - 2876.8s]: things to do in their own, you know, backyards. I mean, it's fantastic. So that's off to you all.

[2877.4s - 2885.3s]: I would say, you know, as as frightening as, you know, COVID-19 is, I also see it as a very unique,

[2885.5s - 2891.4s]: almost once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for us to remake our world by creating those community

[2891.4s - 2896.7s]: connections, you know, just rethinking how what we want to prioritize. You know, I live in

segments.text: Welcome to the Y-Honors Community Podcast. Today we are visiting with Ryan Zinn,
Regenerative Projects Manager at Dr. Bronners. Hey Ryan.
Hey there, how's it going?
Good, how you doing?
You know, not so bad just sort of adjusting to this new reality here when the days and times
of coronavirus for sure.
Yeah, absolutely. Yeah, we're going to have a lot to talk about in terms of coronavirus.
Obviously, you're in the soap business. We've got supply chain issues. All of this relates
also to the sustainability and regeneration work that you're doing all around the planet.
So I'm really looking forward to our discussion today.
Yeah, I'm excited. We're in a very dynamic and changing world.
And you know, it's funny to think sometimes how a soap company could be really caught up in the middle of it.
So I'm excited about our conversation, Aaron.
Great. Well, let me give our audience a bit of a background on you.
Ryan Zinn supports Dr. Bronners International Organic and Fair Trade Supply Chains in Africa, Asia, and the Pacific.
Ryan has worked the last 20 years with small scale farmer organizations to develop agro-ecological strategies that are just and resilient.
Ryan also supports nonprofit partners like the Fair Trade Advocacy Organization, Fair World Project,
and the small farmer crowdfunding platform called Grow Ahead.
And we're going to be mentioning a number of different resources and some videos through our conversation.
And we'll have links to all those in the show notes for folks to reference.
So Ryan, yeah, here we are. And we're dealing with COVID-19.
You're in California. You're at home. Your kids are also at home.
Maybe just as a place to start just because we're all one way or another in this experience together.
How's your day been today? And what's going on in your world right now with the coronavirus?
Yeah, it's a little while. I usually start my day pretty early, mostly because most of our partners are either in Asia or Africa.
And so that gives me an opportunity to either, if I need to touch base with them and I tell you why,
if it wasn't for Zoom and Skype we'd be in a whole lot of trouble these days since all of our travel to all of our partner projects has been really slowed down.
I am just hunkering down from the time being. I've got my two children here at home. I've got a teenager and a twin-ager.
And then I've got my wife who is a pediatric nurse who's also wrapping up her master's in nurse practitioner at UCLA.
So everybody's gone virtual, which has been a big change for them to think through their academic life now online.
And we're just trying to figure it all out now.
Yeah, absolutely. Well, we know for certain that what's happening right now is definitely having an impact on the SOAP companies.
And I'm really curious to ask, I'm assuming that demand has just skyrocketed for the Dr. Bronner's products.
What does that look like in the immediate term? But also, what does that mean over the coming weeks and months in terms of supply chain procurement?
And how resilient are those supplies coming from all around the world?
That's a great question, Aaron. So I think the good news is that we've been demoned by the state of California and the county of San Diego as a quote-unquote essential business.
Certainly, SOAP enhanced annotations will be in high demand for the foreseeable future.
And as such, all our sales have been really booming, which is great on the one hand.
And then I form a part of a really small team.
And our job really is to work with our partners on the ground that produced all of our raw materials and sort of build out our supply chains.
So that includes everything from coconut oil and palm oil on all the way to our essential oils like mint oil.
And right now, our biggest challenge is working with farmers on the ground.
Since many of the countries or regions have actually been facing some sort of variation of either full quarantine or shutdown or limited operation.
And that's kind of, I think, something that is often overlooked.
In fact, it's like you have farmers on the front end of this.
We work with 10,000 small farmers.
Many of them are working in relatively impoverished communities.
And our goal is to not only provide them with a sustained fair trading relationship with Dr. Bronners,
but make sure that they're thriving as well.
And so if they are more or less quarantined to their farmer or to their home,
then make many other food servers here in the United States.
They don't have an income.
They can't put food on the table.
And so not only is it important for our bottom line, but we're really committed to their livelihoods as well.
So just to give you an example, hand sanitizer, which is now flying off the shelves everywhere.
We work with small-scale farmers in Paraguay and Ecuador.
And our farmers, partners in Ecuador, they are just stuck at home because they have a full-on 15-day quarantine.
So they won't actually be able to get their product to port and ship to us.
So we're trying to be as creative as possible.
Certainly, we don't want to abandon our partners in a time of need and go with another sort of cheaper alternative or quicker alternative.
But we also need to make sure that we can continue to make so-open hand sanitizer and the rest of our product.
So I think on top of the day-to-day work that we do, which has its own challenges,
certainly overlaying COVID-19 on top of it, provides another regal that we have to just kind of think through and be pretty creative.
Absolutely. Well, I know that you and the team at Dr. Bronner's are extraordinarily creative and really on the forefront,
the cutting edge of the regenerative and the sustainable movements worldwide.
And I'm so excited to ask you about the ways in which you guys are supporting regenerative agricultural practices around the world.
And what does that mean? I know a lot of our audiences are familiar with the term regenerative.
Some of our audience works in the regenerative realm.
But of course, we also have a lot of folks who are just getting acquainted with the term and what it means.
And clearly, this is going to become a very, very important action item for us all around the planet.
And you guys are leading the way.
So regenerative agriculture, what is it and what are you guys doing?
Well, I mean, I think for us, you know, our sort of journey towards this space in 2020 kind of starts about 15 years ago.
When the Bronner family made this commitment to convert and transfer all of our raw materials or coconut oil, for example,
over to organic sources, what we quickly realized is that without having a lot of, I don't know,
inside into your supply chains, it's really hard to tell if the integrity is there for organic.
Certainly, we didn't know about the working conditions, whether farmers were paid fairly.
And so as a result, we were more or less forced to set up our own supply chains.
So back about 15 years ago, we set up our first supply chain in Sri Lanka to produce coconut oil,
which is our number one ingredient in most of our soaps.
And as a result, we did that not only to have organic integrity, so that we can ensure that the consumer has
a product free from pesticides and is grown sustainably.
But certainly, we also wanted to produce under fair trade conditions as well.
So that means that farmers are paid fair prices, they're paid promptly.
We're not going to abandon them if they face a drought or COVID-19 or what have you.
And so we wanted to make sure that that was really our foundation.
And over time, what we realized is that we really wanted to take it further.
And so we've kind of been approaching this idea of regenerative organic agriculture as a way to not only
ensure that we have a stable supply chain for ourselves for sure.
But really, I think the big thing is thinking it through the lens of climate change.
So what we know is that climate change has already been having a big impact on farmers around the world,
whether they call it climate change or something else.
But really, if it were like the past 10 or 20 years,
we'd be seeing increases of crop loss, more pest and disease problems for farmers.
And this is leading to all sorts of things, migration to the cities,
losing land, those types of things.
And so our goal is to really improve our practices on the ground under this sort of banner of
regenerative organic.
And really what that means is a couple of different things just in terms of general principles.
One, in nature, nature has no monoculture.
So really, our focus is to diversify as much as we can with our small farmer partners.
And that means to them to diversify into other crops and other systems that,
quite frankly, we may never actually use in our own supply chains to make soap.
So for example, in Ghana and West Africa, where we see a number of our farmers actually grow
cocoa to make chocolate, there it's a very, very heavily pesticide dependent crop, where they
just sprayed, fund aside, left and right just because of the climatic conditions and the practices.
And so our goal is to get those farmers off the pesticide treadmill, improve their practices,
which will not only improve their resiliency and improve their food security,
but also provide some additional income.
While we are able to provide fair prices for the products that we buy,
the rest of the marketplace, quite frankly, is just not fair.
And so we want to make sure that we can find fair prices for virtually everything that farmers
produce, whether that is sold and distributed in local markets, or we find them premium buyers
in the United States or in Europe.
Well, that's tremendous. You guys are going well above and beyond your own direct needs and
interests with these farmers. That's really remarkable.
Yeah, for us, it's been a slow process. When you start to convert farmers from these long,
sort of seeded experience of using chemicals to farm, it's a long sort of transitional
process. And so what we want to do is accompany farmers during that process, but also provide them
incentives so that they can sort of, you know, whether the changes that they are facing on the
ground themselves, you know, quite frankly, depending on what you grow. Sometimes organic may
have higher labor costs, for example, or require you to spend more time out in your field.
So we want to make sure that as much as possible, really the true cost, what it takes to produce
a regenerative and fair product is reflected in our relationship with farmers.
You know, it's interesting. I've spoken with a number of farmers over the years about the
often the increased labor requirements associated with organic practices. But on the other hand,
there's an offset coming from no longer needing to buy these expensive chemical inputs. And I'm
curious with these farmers you've worked with in general, how does their economic performance
trend over time as they convert to organic and then build in a regenerative framework?
I would say it really varies from place to place. You know, some places you have quite a bit more
labor, depending on the cropping, you know, system. So for example, all of the mint that we use in our,
or mint oil we use in our, you know, most famous peppermint, so comes from Uttar Pradesh and in India,
where they grow mint to make essential oils, but the rotations as well, things from wheat,
paddy rice and those types of things. And so really our goal is to figure out a way to support them
during that transition period where in some cases their cost may go up because of labor, for example,
or their yields may go down. But once our experiences is once you get over the hump that that
transitional period where you actually certified organic, you can receive that organic premium,
then you know, things begin to balance out quite a bit better in the favor of farmers.
Really kind of our goal, you know, once we go through this transition period that's both required
for the marketplace, but also just for soil to kind of like come back alive again and to be able
to produce healthily, then you have many, many more options. And so after that sort of investment
of time and if you're growing, you know, tree crops, there's quite a bit of investment in terms of
ceilings, for example. We want to make sure that farmers have sort of a stable diversified sort of
farm economy that can sort of, you know, whether the the, the changing either climatic conditions or even
the market conditions. Yeah, yeah, that's really interesting. Well, speaking of the peppermint,
Dr. Bronner's soap, I've got some of that in my bathroom. So I'm a daily user in a big fan.
Well, I'm wondering, can you help connect the dots a little more and paint more of a picture for folks?
What is the connection between regenerative agriculture, soil and climate crisis?
Sure. Okay, so that's a really good question, Aaron. You know, one of the things that we often
think about when we think about climate change that either it's, you know, sort of exhaust coming
out of cars, tailpipes or, you know, factories spewing contaminants into the atmosphere, sort of on the,
you know, emissions end of things. Or we also think of things like solar panels, for example,
as a way to kind of mitigate against some of the bigger and broader kind of climate change
challenges. What most folks may not realize is that agriculture or industrialized agriculture,
in fact, is one of the larger, you know, sources of greenhouse gases. So everything from,
you know, mechanized agriculture is a big combine of tractors to the production of food, for example,
infertilizers, pesticides. But even just the simple fact of turning over soil and like plowing
and very heavily actually releases carbon stored in that soil into the atmosphere. And so this sort
of quote unquote, you know, industrial agricultural experience we've been doing now for the last six
or 70 years has actually created quite a bit of greenhouse gas emissions, you know, that have been
going up into the atmosphere. So we see a lot of potential for regenerative agriculture to not only
stop those emissions, but actually sort of restore this carbon cycle, which basically means that
soil can act as a carbon sink, suck all that CO2 out of the atmosphere, put it into the soil,
which is not only beneficial for the climate, but it's also really, really important for plants
and healthy soil. Although that turns into actual sort of nutrients to have a very healthy soil
profile. And so that's been pretty much our goal in terms of how we've been approaching farming
at all of our projects. Really, it's, this really combination is to implement practices that's a
Quester carbon, we're appropriate, but also build up our soil health. And so that's one of the things
that is probably, you know, a very simple concept to do, but it's one thing that really provides a
lot of stability for farmers. They're able to actually absorb those climate shocks, where they're
it's drought, not enough rain, too much rain, high temperatures, those types of things. But it also
acts as a way for us to sort of turn back on some of the damage we've been doing through climate
change. So really, our kind of focus here is to see agriculture done regeneratively and organically
as a way for us to address multiple things at once. Turn back climate change, have farmers feed
our local communities and to be able to produce a product like Dr. Brotter's soap that's done in a
way that's fairly and as cleanly as possible. Yeah, absolutely. And one of the things that here
at the Y on Earth community, obviously, we really emphasize for folks is the critical role that each
of us as individuals plays as a consumer with our purchasing decisions where we're directing our
consumer demand signals. And I'm wondering, can you speak to a bit about the dynamics that you see
out in the marketplace? And of course, it's a it's a segue into the regenerative organics
certification that I know we're all really, really excited about. But what do you see out there in
the marketplace in terms of the importance of the consumer demand signals? Well, one thing I think
which has been really exciting for me is that one, I think consumers, ethical consumers are seeing
that they want to go quote unquote above and beyond organic and maybe even fair trade. And they're
seeing climate change as one of the big existential threats that it is not only to their communities,
but to the foods that they like. You know, I always tell folks if you really want to get freaked out,
you know, above and beyond COVID-19, just type in your favorite food into Google and climate change,
whether it's chocolate, coffee, wine, bread, there's been a huge number of sort of like, you know,
evidences and impacts that were seen throughout different supply chains. And so I think
consumers are becoming increasingly savvy about that. And so as a result of all the fine work that's
been done by, you know, farmers organizations and other nonprofits and NGOs, I think farmers are
produced consumers are really looking to to make sure that that consumer dollar that they're
spending really goes to those products that reflect their values. It's not just enough to be organic
or just enough to be fair trade. They want to basically look at the suite of values altogether
on one product. And so I think that of course is actually very, very encouraging. It means that we've
got this sort of emerging consumer base that's really willing to put their money where their
mouth is, but I think it's really positive. On the other hand, what you have now in the marketplace,
other than, you know, claims like organic, for example, which is regulated at the federal level,
you're seeing all sorts of claims in the marketplace that's regenerative of this or free-range that.
And none of these claims are in fact regulated or have any basically, you know, sort of assurance behind
them. And so one of the things that we did at Dr. Bronner's was look to connect with other
like-minded organizations and companies to create a standard and process that really put a whole
lot of sort of like, force and that validity behind the claims. And so we partnered with the
Rhode Island Institute out of Pennsylvania, Patagonia, and a number of other NGOs and farmers'
organizations to create a draft or pilot standard called the regenerative organic certification
or rock standard. And so from there, our goal was really to be able to try to bring together all
of our imported values. So organic certainly was there, fairness, performers and farm workers
was certainly front and center, and then also looking at soil health and animal welfare.
You know, one of the things that we look at is like when we look at a farm or a product,
we want to make sure that all those values are there. Well, it's really tough for a consumer to
try to figure that out all on their own. Heck, I'm, you know, in this business and sometimes it's
also tough for me when I go to the supermarket to figure out if the claims that a product
are making are in fact real or just re-washing. So our goal was to be able to create a standard
that reflects our values and then can be verified, which means that a third party will go out and
certify to it. And then the consumer can know that, hey, look, all my values are encapsulated in
this product. Yeah, that's so powerful. Well, we're really excited about the regenerative organic
certification and the why on earth community, I know is going to be doing a whole lot in the coming
months to help build awareness, educate and mobilize around that out in the marketplace.
And, you know, it makes me think also about a lot of the other ways in which we're all engaged in
cultivating a more regenerative oriented culture. And I know you have some thoughts about
what living regeneratively means in addition to whatever soap we might choose to buy.
What are some of those? Well, I tell you what, I mean, it's actually, you know, maybe the one
silver lining of the COVID-19 crisis is that, you know, it's really kind of forced our hand to do
two things. I think one is to look like our at our own home. You know, I saw a couple of stats
really in the last maybe 10 days where, you know, the sales of organic seeds have just gone through
the roof. And so I see that as a really positive step. Even if it's a really small, you know,
couple of containers of herbs you have on your porch or your balcony or, you know, on your windows
seal or you can vert your entire front lawn to a home garden, I think those are really powerful
connection because I think on multiple levels, one, if we can actually actively participate in the
growing of our own food, even if it's relatively smaller, symbolic. I think there's just a very
clear connection that you would see with the rest of the food that you buy. You have a greater
appreciation that all of the work that farmers and farm workers go through and how hard it is and
what an enchanted is to actually get fair and organic food to your front door, to your super
markets. I think that's really important. And the other thing that I think is exciting for me to see
is that there's more and more examples liberation happening right now, which I think is really,
really critical. I don't think any of us can go it alone. Doesn't matter how much money we have or
how much space we have to grow, whatever we have, I think being able to collaborate and depend upon
your neighbors, I think is really, really critical. So I've seen some really great examples just
in the last week of people working together either to help their neighbor go get, you know, they're
medicine at the pharmacy, for example. I've really came together and shared their resources on my
street for those folks that didn't get any toilet paper because somebody was hoarding them. So
it was a great way for us to be able to say how can we collaborate in a way and, you know,
sort of had that mutual aid network within your own community. I think that's really, really critical.
So to me, it's a couple of things. One, it's making sure those relationships locally within your
street or your neighborhood are really, really strong. And then second, it's also just basically
getting your hands dirty, they going out there and kind of growing what you can. Because I think
that sort of connection to the earth is so much more tangible when you can do it yourself.
As opposed to thinking about it, you know, theoretically about some farmer, you know, far away from you,
you know, kind of doing their own thing and you have no real connection to them. So those are for me,
I think, are probably the two sort of biggest and most exciting things I've seen. And then I should just
add, you know, one of the things that we've been really focusing on is I think it's great to buy
organically and regeneratively as much as you can. But we need to take all of that energy and then
put it into making good public policies so that way we can support farmers to transition regeneratively
as well. So there's a lot of great discussions happening right now to make sure that farmers are
supported as they transition to regenerative practices, whether that's training to the USDA.
One of the things that we think has got a lot of potential is for like school districts and
hospitals to have regenerative purchasing policies. So that all of the produce and the food that they
get comes from regenerative sources. That would be one solid way to support those farmers,
make that transition because sometimes the marketplace isn't so kind to farmers. And so we want to
make sure that they've got good long-term stable contracts so that they can actually make those
investments in those regenerative practices. Yeah, obviously a lot of different ways we can all
help support these efforts. And I think it's becoming with COVID-19 increasingly clear to us
how vulnerable some of the food supply chains can be and how much we truly depend on the farmers,
the folks growing the food. And when I was writing the book Why on Earth a few years ago,
I talked about three different ways we can think about how we're procuring our food,
grow, know, and show for short-hand. So grow some of your own, know some farmers in the vicinity from
whom you can source things and then show what those things we are buying at the store or through
e-commerce. Through third-party certifications show that those food-inververged products are coming
to us with good treatment of people, good treatment of soil, good treatment of water.
So the grow, know, show framework seems to hold up, I would say even more robustly in the context
of what we're all experiencing right now with coronavirus. Oh, 100%. And I think this is a really,
it's a great opportunity but it's going to be a very challenging time for small farmers all over,
you know, quite frankly, if they don't have a couple of months of, you know, just cash flow to be
able to weather sort of these challenges, it's going to be really challenging. So I think really
the big thing that I've been seeing in sort of my community is figuring out how to support,
you know, small and independent businesses or farmers or like you said, using sort of those e-commerce
options if those products aren't quite, you know, available, you know, in your local community.
